title: 115_hr2306
content: The Act is titled the "Putting Main Street FIRST Act" and includes a Transaction Tax under a new subchapter in the Internal Revenue Code. The "Putting Main Street FIRST Act" includes a Transaction Tax on covered transactions with a rate of 0.03 percent of the specified base amount. The specified base amount is the fair market value of a security or the payment amount for a derivative. A covered transaction refers to any purchase, subject to certain exceptions. The "Putting Main Street FIRST Act" includes a Transaction Tax on covered transactions with a rate of 0.03 percent of the specified base amount. Exceptions from tax apply to purchases and derivatives traded on qualified boards or exchanges in the United States, or involving United States persons. The "Putting Main Street FIRST Act" imposes a Transaction Tax on covered transactions, with exceptions for certain short-term indebtedness traded on qualified boards or exchanges in the United States. The term "security" is defined as any share of stock in a corporation. The "Putting Main Street FIRST Act" imposes a Transaction Tax on covered transactions, with exceptions for certain short-term indebtedness traded on qualified boards or exchanges in the United States. The term "security" includes shares of stock, partnership interests, notes, bonds, derivatives, and other forms of indebtedness. A derivative is defined as any contract whose value is determined by reference to securities. The term "derivative" includes commodities actively traded, currencies, rates, prices, indices, and other items prescribed by the Secretary. Exceptions include securities lending and similar financing transactions. The term "derivative" excludes securities lending, sale-repurchase transactions, insurance contracts, annuities, and endowments. The tax imposed by this section shall be paid by qualified board or exchange as defined by section 1256(g)(7) or by a broker in the United States for transactions not on a qualified board or exchange. The tax imposed by this section is paid by the purchaser if a United States person in a transaction described in subsection (d)(1)(A), and by the seller if the purchaser is not a United States person. In a transaction described in subsection (d)(1)(B), the payor pays if a United States person, and the payee pays if the payor is not a United States person. Exchanges are treated according to the provisions of this section. In general, an exchange is treated as the sale and purchase of property by each party involved. Certain distributions are treated as exchanges for stock. Payments related to derivatives are treated as separate transactions. The section also applies to transactions by controlled foreign corporations. "For tax purposes, a controlled foreign corporation is considered a United States person. Special rules apply for tax payments on transactions involving controlled foreign corporations, with United States shareholders responsible for paying the tax proportionally." The shareholder must pay a proportion of tax based on their ownership of stock in a controlled foreign corporation. The Secretary will implement this section in consultation with the SEC and CFTC. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission will provide guidance and regulations to prevent avoidance of information reporting on covered transactions. Additionally, a new section will be added to allow a credit with respect to certain tax-favored accounts to offset transaction tax. The new section allows for a credit to offset transaction tax on contributions to certain tax-favored accounts. A credit of 0.03 percent of qualified tax-favored account contributions is allowed against the tax for the taxable year. Qualified contributions include amounts contributed to qualified retirement plans and Archer MSAs that are deductible or excludable from gross income. The text discusses deductions allowed for health savings accounts, qualified tuition programs, qualified ABLE programs, and Coverdell education savings accounts. Additionally, it mentions information reporting requirements for controlled foreign corporations. Corporations must comply with new reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code, including amendments to section 6038(a)(1)(B) and section 1324(b)(2) of title 31. The Internal Revenue Code has new reporting requirements for corporations, including amendments to section 6038(a)(1)(B) and section 1324(b)(2) of title 31. A new tax on trading transactions, effective after December 31, 2018, is introduced under section 36C.
